come out of hidden flaps in the wings, and the new General 
Grievous looks really great.


Down sides:

You have to take two of General 
Grievous's arms off so he fits in his Star Fighter.

author: kelano28
title: A Great Improvement!
review:
While I personally do not own the first Grievous Starfighter (7656), my friend does and I got the chance to build it and swoosh it around a bit.  I liked it a lot considering the piece count, and for $20 it was a great deal.   However, between the lack of detail, slightly off shape (I'm a big fan of Grievous' ship, Soulless One) and the so-so Grievous figure, I never picked the set up.  I was close to regretting the decision when Lego announced the release of a new set, imagine my excitement!

I picked this up the second I found it, and just now got the chance to put it together.  Here are my thoughts:

The Build
Here we have a very fun build, IMO.  We start with the great minifigs and the simple but neat workshop where Grievous is operated upon.  Next you build the middle of the starfighter using similar yet buffed techniques to get that brown and tan striped pattern.  This is followed by the wings and finally the miscellaneous details to the set (engines, missiles, etc).  The build can take a while if you pace yourself (I watched all of Episode III while making this!) and it uses some great techniques to get the shape just right.
9/10

The Design
This is where I think this set shines.  The cockpit, for one, looks great and opens smoothly, but I won't ruin the technique that accomplishes this feat!  The manual (and other reviews) suggest taking off Grievous' side arms when placing him in the cockpit, but I found simply folding them into his chest allows him to fit completely.  The missiles in the wings are awesome as well.  Something about hidden compartments that close and stay flush with the model really adds to a set for me.  The tail fin raises and lowers, but this is nothing earth-shattering here.  There is also a large missile on the bottom that can be removed and deployed to your liking.
10/10

The Minifigs
Outstanding.  First we have the General himself, and he is a joy to look at.  IMO a much better rendition of the menacing clanker, with just the right angles to his neck, legs, and arms.  He also comes with 4 lightsabers in pearl silver.  Next is Nahdar Vebb.  To those who have the Home One set this will be a familiar figure for the most part, but still a welcome addition and a great young jedi to have.  Finally we have the A4-D Repair Droid.  This minifig consists of 18 pieces!  There is a sticker for the face of the droid but I think it makes it look very good and is worth applying.  All in all, outstanding figs here.
9/10

The Price
Here's the drawback, like most new sets these days.  $50 is pretty steep for the set, but honestly I don't feel ripped off and I would get the set again at this price.  Do I think $40 is a better price point? Of course, and you can probably spend your money more efficiently on Lego, however I think this set is fantastic and if you're a fan of the ship or the General then you are doing yourself a disservice by waiting any longer!
7/10

Happy Building!

author: desire4one
title: General Grievous is Flying in Style
review:
This set was a lot of fun to put together.  It took me about 1 hour to put together including the minifigs and table.  It seems simple, but has a lot of great features that make the set stand out a bit.  And finally, a General Grievous that looks good!

The ship looks par on from the movie.  I have to say, thats the first time I've seen that in a lego set.  Although not difficult to build, it is time cosuming, as each engine is pretty extensive.  It has some great features:  Flick-fire Missle bays fold out of the engines.  They are perfectly hidden, you can't tell they exist from the outside.  The end "rutter" folds up and down just like in the films and gives support when the ship is sitting somewhere.  And best of all, the cockpit!  It actually slides back and forth rather than opening.  Finally! 

The minifigs are great.  General Grievous has a really nicely scultped body, and detail paint is plentiful.  You can see his rotting, evil eyes quite easily.  When all arms are attatched, it actually looks like he is swinging lightsabers around, in a variety of angles.  The whole figure just looks good.  And of course, we get a Mon Calamari Jedi.  Can't go wrong with that.

Even the little chair/station looks neat.  The chair especially.

The only complaints I have are with the cockpit.  Theres not a lot of space inside the cockpit.  So little in fact, that you can't even get a regular minifigure to sit inside.  And if you planning on putting Grievous in there, tear off his extra arms and jam him in there.

Pros

  • Although it was still a little overpriced ($49.99), I didn't feel ripped off or dissapointed.
  • The ship is a very good replica from the film.  I challenge you to find a better one.
  • Minifigs are pretty cool, with an excellent General Grievous.
  • Ship features are simple yet neat.  I haven't seen the sliding cockpit idea before.
  • Lots of dark gray pieces.  They can be used for anything from stone to dull metal.

Cons

  • The cockpit has a very shallow depth and doesn't allow other minifigs to sit inside, they're heads get squished by the cockpit.

Overall I was very pleased with the set and strongly recommend any Lego fan to get it.  General Grievous fans should feel ashamed if you don't make this part of your collection.

author: LegoAficionado
title: Can You Believe it- An Amazing set that is just the right Cost!
review:
This is the fourth of five Star Wars Sets that I recently bought. And when buying these sets, this one was one of the sets that I was determined to get.

I originally bought the first General Grievous Set back in 2005, and I loved it, except for the fact that Grievous' arms were positioned in an awkward way, so that you could not pose him fighting a jedi. Then Grievous' starfighter set was released only a few years ago, and when I was hoping for an improved General, I was disappointed. Now this set comes along and guess what, I was thrilled to see that Lego remade General Grievous, so let's go on to the review...

The Minifigs:

The minifigs that come with the set are AMAZING! First of all, the one minifig you got the set for is of course General Grievous, and this version of him, is a beast. New body mold, new legs (two separate legs to be exact) and four new arm pieces, along with the new chrome lightsabers of the clone wars series. This version is not only mostly movie accurate but is very accurate to the show as well, and the level of detail is evident in he figure itself, no need to say how amazing this guy is.

Then the set also comes with Grievous' medical droid, which only appears in one episode of the Clone Wars series, but he is a welcome addition to any collection. Only problem with this guy is that he is very clunky, and can topple over if not stuck to the neat little medical base. Also, his head is a sticker not a printed head, and that may bother some, but it does not bother me.

Finally, Nadar Vehb (or how ever you spell it) is included, and personally the Mon Calamari head is rare, and a nice collectible, but overall I would have preferred Lego to release a better known jedi in this set, maybe Kit Fisto since he was in the episode this set depicts. Plus maybe a clone trooper would have been nice to, but I am glad that Lego at least put in a jedi into the set.

The Build:

In comparison to the last Grievous starfighter, this one is larger, more detailed, and overall superbly brilliant! The build is moderately challenging and keeps you enticed throughout. I personally had a blast finding out how each piece added to the finished product and when it all comes together, it gives you one of those moments where you really appreciate what Lego does. In other words, a nice Eureka! moment. 

The ship is very detailed and has some very nice pieces. The aesthetic design also translates into the feature of the ship with some nicely hidden flickfire missile compartments on the side, giving you a total of four missiles. A nice deployable bomb from the bottom of the ship (no gears there but you have to use your fingers, not much though to complain about), and the cockpit function and landing gear are very nicely done. This time, only the cockpit slides open rather than the entire nose of the ship sliding to open (which the last starfighter did). 

Grievous fits into the starfighter, but as many reviewers pointed out, you have to remove the two side arms that extend off from the main arms, in order for him to fit in. Personally I have no problem with this since you can attach the two arms to the head of the medical chair that the set comes with, which brings me to talk about the medical station.

In short, the medical station is okay. The chair is nice and the lightsaber rack is a good place for Grievous' weapons to be stored. All in all, the station is more of a place to put the extra minifigs when you are not using them, and it only adds to the rest of the set.

Overall: 

The set is a much needed improvement in comparison to the old starfighter and Grievous. The ship is excellent, no flaws at all. The figures are fantastic, and Grievous truly shines.

Pros:
-New and Excellent Grievous (w/ 4 lightsabers and a blaster)
-A Jedi and nice medical station
-Superb Starfighter
-Nice features to the Starfighter
-Great Set at a Very Decent Price (this set actually has a good price to it)

Cons:
-Stickers (but there are only four or so, not a big deal)
-Medical Droid is a bit clunky

So Overall, this is if not the best star wars set that I own, and I own quite a few.
Great Figures, Great Starfighter, And awesome features, for $50, and about 500 pieces,
this set is truly worth buying. If you have the money and you want a great set, get this
one. A perfect 5/5 in everything!

author: Carl
title: AMAZING!
review:
WOW! This version of General Grievous' Starfighter is HEAPS better than the old one, and the minifigs and features of the ship are aweosme.

A4-D - 5/5

A4-D is Grievous' medical droid who conducts repairs on his robotic parts and armour. He has a saw and some other mechanical medic equipment. But sadly, A4-D's face is a STICKER! But seeing as the rest of him is cool, and the sticker isn't too bad, I will forgive LEGO on this one occasion. 

Nahdar Vebb - 5/5

Nahdar Vebb is Kit Fisto's former padawan who passed the Jedi Trials and became a Knight. The minifig is awesome. The Mon Calamari headpiece that LEGO used in the 'Home One' is still awesome and I really can't see what people are complaining about with it. He has nice double sided Jedi robes that look great and a blue lightsaber. He is a great addition to this set. 

General Grievous - 10/5

WOW! This General Grievous minifig is AMAZING! He looks fantastic! He is very detailed and has four lightsabers just like in the movies. I have no problems with this minifig at all. To avoid two of his lightsabers having to be horizontally positioned, I just put two of those spare clip-like pieces, one on each arm, and attach Grievous' other arms onto them. This allows all lightsabers to face the same way and also allows more dynamic posing. Overall, the new Grievous is one of the best minifigs EVER.

Medical Bay - 5/5

The medical bay is pretty cool. Grievous fits nicely in the chair and the lightsaber rack is cool. I would have maybe like it to be a little bigger, but I don't mind it as it is. Operating on Grievous is fun and it also comes with a gun for Grievous.


Starfighter - 5/5

The Starfighter itself is awesome. The cockpit slides much better than the old version and I find that Grievous fits fine inside, and I really like the fold out flick-fire missiles, though I would have preferred them if there was only one block with holes so the missiles would be easier to fire. The 180 degree guns are a nice addition and the missile on the bottom is cool, however it doesn't fire or fall off so you have to throw it or just leave it on the bottom. The landing gear is pretty cool but I like to just leave it in landing position.

Overall 

Overall, this is an absolute MUST HAVE set and I would definitely recommend it to any LEGO fan.

author: legoclone
title: Very nice improvement over the old version!
review: Nice, Nice, Nice!   This is one of the best âdo-overâsâ that Lego has done.   The General Grievous finally has a starfighter that looks mean enough to go into battle flanked by a couple MagnaGuard Starfighters.   The ship is beefier and more solid.  The most important upgrade is General Grievous himself.  The figure that came with the old starfighter was pathetic.  That one looked like he would have a hard time fighting one of his own battle droids much less taking on some Jedi.  This one is a vast improvement.   To go along with the bigger and better Grievous they have included a bigger cockpit that melds nicely with the overall ship.  It has a brand new painted canopy design that I really like.   I usually donât really pay much attention to the exta little âsceneâ kits that come with these but this one isnât half bad.  It gives you a handy place to store his light saber collection and the chair is actually a pretty cool design that I may attempt to re-create for other applications.  I also like the maintenance bot.  Heâs different from anything we have seen before.  Overall I give Lego an A for this set.

author: abertr
title: A new general in town
review:
This new set for 2010 was well worth the wait.  

The Mini Figs
The new Grievous mini-fig is well detailed.  It is a dramatic improvement over the last generation.  The head is very well detailed, following along with the more recent Star Wars mini-figs.

The Jedi apprentice is slight more basic.  He is from one short episode on the TV show and is just the Mon Calamari head from set 7754 with a jedi body.  The droid that services Grievous is well detailed.

There is a chair and lightsaber holder part to this set I will include here;  It is supposed to be the place where Grievous gets repaired.  It is a neat design but I can only believe this was thrown into the set to increase the brick count and to "add value".  (I have become a skeptic after reading the "Lego Star Wars Visual Dictionary" as they eluded to adding figures or parts to hit their price target).  I would have liked to see this chair set as a part of a larger set.

The Ship
It is a fairly standard build.  The cockpit has a neat design.  The top "slides" forward like in the movie and the mini-fig has a decent amount of space.  I have read other reviews that all complained that you have to take the arms off to get him in his own ship.  Well, being a movie purist, Grievous didn't normally walk around with all 4 of his arms out.  He only used them in combat...

As a fairly new collector of star wars I knew I had to have the set for the mini-figs, it would be an amazing set if the price was more in line with the product...

author: Firox_5000
title: Great ship but  very expensive
review:
I recently got this set from my local Argos branch.

 

The set contains 454 pieces inside a really nice box with good art work and shiny print. It contains 3 figures. A droid which serves grievous, Nadar who is a random but fairly good jedi who has the same head as Admiral ackbar in the homeone. The set also includes a new and improoved General Grievous who has a very detailed head,arms and legs and the cool metalic lightsabers.

 

The Ship looks very cool and neat and much better than the 2007 one. it feels very sturdy in most places as well as being bigger too. The set features hidden flick fire missiles,A bomb hidden underneath the ship and a sliding cockpit which you simply push the top forwards or back to put grievous inside.

 

The set also includes a seat for grievous to sit on as well as space for lightsaber storage and a random shot gun.

 

the set is amazing and I recomend you buy this if youre a fan of Star wars.  My only complaints of the set are that the thing on the back is a bit odd when in flight mode.

 

For Â£45.00 the set seems pretty small even for a star wars set. For a reasonable price I think it should cost Â£34.99.

 

But still I suggest you  buy it.

author: Aspernatio
title: General Grevious is Back- In Style!
review:
General Overview
 

This set is based off of the Star Wars: The Clone Wars episode in which Kit Fisto and his former apprentice, Nahdar Vebb, attempt to infiltrate Grevious' secret base.  Lego did a good job in there rendition of the chapter, with obvious attempts to emulate his medical bay, surgeon, and starfighter.  It would be right for one to expect Kit Fisto to be included, however the set fairs fine without him. 
 

The overall design of the set is quite functional, and easily surpasses expectations.   Operating on Grevious is enjoyable, and the sliding cockpit on his ship is both realistic and fun to watch.  However, Grevious himself is difficult to position, and very stiff in nature.  It can be quite difficult to position his legs, and it would seem the the general is in need of an oiling!


 

Mini figures

  • General Grevious

Grevious' Aesthetics are a superb improvement from his former mini figure.  The molds used on his head, torso, and limbs are all unique, and the coloring was done perfectly.  As mentioned before, his playability is somewhat reduced by his broad stiffness.  Furthermore, in order for him to fit into his Starfighter, two of his arms must be removed.  While this follows realism, it can become quite cumbersome when trying to make a quick escape!
 

  • Nahdar Vebb

This is perhaps the first time that we have seen a Mon Calamari available in a set priced at $50.  I myself am a huge fan of the squid like beings, and was enthralled at the prospect of acquiring one.  I cannot say that I was let down, as Nahdar's likeness was created with both precision and good looks.  His head piece is painted wonderfully, with the level of detail going down to brown blotches on his forehead.  While he is adorned in generic jedi robes, his wonderful head more than makes up for it!

 

  • A4-D Medical Droid

A4-D, Grevious' personal surgeon, is an unnecessary yet interesting addition to the set.  He has a strong resemblance to the droid featured in the aforementioned episode, and is equipped with several medical instruments.  Sawing off and reattaching Limbs to Grevious never gets old, and A4-D's mischievous expression adds all the more realism to the situation.  It should be noted that A4-D's head is a decal, but it is hardly noticeable.

 

Starfighter

As the main feature of the set, the starfighter aims to please.  I believe that it succeeded in doing so.  The classy craft features an assortment of death dealing weapons, ranging from front-mounted blasters to concealed flick-to-fire missiles.  Additionally, hidden beneath the main fuselage, is a particularly large missile, which looks very capable of wreaking havoc amongst enemy fighters. 

In appearance, the sleek contours of the craft does not disappoint.  Sporting a both a simplistic landing gear device and clever cabin opening mechanism, Grevious will have no complaints to the manufacturer.  

Pros:
 

  • Very aesthetically pleasing
     
  • A cabin design which slides forward to allow entry
  • Landing Gear which facilitates a stable position when idle
  • Concealed flick-to-fire missiles
  • A single belly-mounted massive missile
  • Front Mounted blasters

Cons:
 

  • In order to fit into the cockpit Grevious must remove two of his arms.
  • Flick-to-Fire Missiles (For those who are not found of them)
     
  • Several Decals (For those who are not found of them)

Medical Bay

The small little medical bay, while unobtrusive and nondescript, is still a welcome addition to the set.  The operating chair fits Grevious perfectly, while his weapons cache is handy for storing light sabers when he's off flying his star fighter.  This portion of the set was executed quite nicely, and there is little to complain about. 

Pros:
 

  • A very fitting, swiveling operating chair (360 degree rotation)
  • A weapons cache handy for storing off-hand equipment

Cons:
 

  • Perhaps a bit to small

Equipment

  • (3x) Blue Lightsabers
  • (2x) Green Lightsabers
  • (1x) Blaster Rifle
  • A4-D's Operating Accessories

Conclusion

While you get quite a lot of variety for your money, I believe that this set was priced a bit too high.  However, that seems to be the general standpoint of all sets now, so there's little to complain about.  For the same price, you could purchase either the Tie-Defender, or Cad bane's Speeder.  After consider all three options, I've concluded that General Grevious Starfighter strikes a good balance between mini figures and parts.  In it, you receive the largest amount of parts (454 vs. 304 (Tie Defender) and 318 (Cad Bane's Speeder)) and a moderate amount of mini figures (3 vs. 2 (Tie Defender) and 5 (Cad Bane's Speeder))

I would recommend that anyone considering purchasing this set consider their options, and make a decision based upon their own preferences.  Of course, that Mon Calamari Nahdar Webb is pretty tempting...

author: Pius
title: THE COOLEST GENERAL GRIEVOUS SET YET!
review:
PROS - I enjoyed playing and displaying this set ever since I got it (which wasn't very long ago). I love how the weapons are arranged. I like these minifigures and I think all of these minifigures are unique, especially General Grievous.

CONS - I dislike how it is so hard to fit General Grievous inside the flying area of his ship. I also dislike how the parts of the general's droid fall off so easily.

author: starwarsman52
title: Top 5 favorite sets EVER
review:
This starfighter is an incredible buy. Some people may say it is overpriced but I can understand why LEGO made it $50. You get 3 exclusive minifigs, the ship AND greviouses chair and many different features. I cannot put into words how much better this version is than the old one. Grievous's droid is pretty cool. Nadhar is ok considering they used the same exact head from Admiral Ackbar from the Home One. But the Grievous fig, WOW! It is so detailed. From his eyes to his 4 arms to his armour. The ship is incredible. It's perfect size. plus has many different lethal weapons. The first ones are 180 degree blaster turrets, then under the fighter you get a bomb, and from the wings you can pull out 2 sets of flick fire missiles.
  • Pros:
  • crazy good grievous
  • many great features
  • 5 lightsabers and blaster
  • awesome sliding cockpit

  •  Cons:
  • could have made grievous's head better
  • should have made nahdar's had more like clone wars one
  • should have put in Kit Fisto since this set is from "Grievous's Lair" from the clone wars

author: sudorum
title: Obvious Contrasts
review:
I always considered the original 7656 General Grievous Starfighter to be a rather average set. The Grievous minifigure wasn't too great, but he was General Grievous, so I was content. However, this set not only puts to shame the original Grievous minifigure, but his starfighter as well. The new Grievous is so different from his former self that it's hard to even tell that the two minifigures are supposed to represent the same character from the movies. The starfighter also appears vastly different than the original. It's not as simplistic, and its playability functions are improved. The cockpit still slides effortlessly forward and blasters still raise from the top of the ship. The major improvements are the concealed flick fire missiles which extend from the side of the ship to surprise enemy passerby. Unfortunately, a problem does arise if you try to fit Grievous into his ship with all four arms attached to his frame. 

Except for the new minifigure additions and the random chair and lightsaber rack, this set is essentially an upgraded version of the older model. The 7656 set is supposedly from Episode III and this set here from the clone wars, but it really makes no difference. Unless of course General Grievous was an albino in Episode III.

author: KLOKRIECHER
title: LEGO Star Wars - General Grievous' Starfighter Review
review:
This is a cool set to have and it's fun to play with as well.

Parts

This set has 454 pieces and it was 50 USD when it was on sale. That means that the price per piece ratio was 11 cents per piece which is a really good value for what we get here.

Minifigures

This set has 3 minifigs which are new. The Nahdar Vebb minifig looks very nice with his mon calamari head and he also has a double-printed torso and a blue lightsaber. The other new minifig is EV-A4D who is the medical droid. This droid has lot's of tool. The only things which I don't like about this figure are that the face of this droid is a sticker and that the minifig doesn't stand very well. The last figure we get is General Grievous. Grievous looks MUCH BETTER than the version we got in the past.

The build

The build is very nice and it will take you a while. We also get a few sticker to put on.

The completed model

[img]http://www.klokriecher.de/gallery_pics/l/8095-1.jpg[/img]

This set has a chair with a lightsaber cache for Grievous and the starfighter itself. The chair can sviwel full 360Â° and you can also adjust the back. The starfighter has a storage compartment where you can hide the flick-missiles on each side. On the bottom is a bomb which you can take off. The only problem I have with this play feature that there's no button which you can use to drop the bomb. On the top we get some turrets which you can adjust up and/or down. I also like the engine details on the back of this model and the landing-gear on the back can sviwel as well. What I also like about this starfighter is that the windscreen can be opened very nice and easy, too and I also love the way how you can slide this piece. You can also put Grievous in the inside of the cockpit but you have to take two of his arms off which I don't like. I think this is a much better version of the General Grievous' Starfighter we got a few years ago.

Summary

All in all this set is an great set and I would HIGHLY recommend you to get this. You can find this set on eBay, BrickLink and Amazon for sure. Here is the link where you can check out the full gallery I made for this set on my website: http://www.klokriecher.de


Videos I made of this set:

Stopmotion

Review

author: Shistavanen_brick
title: The general and his ship - making the galaxy insecure.
review:
Some well-meaning relatives gave me this last Christmas and at first I remember wishing they had found an original trilogy set instead. I thought, "well, it's STAR WARS at the end of the day, so why not..." But first impressions aren't always the ones to last. After putting it together I viewed it in a new light, so to speak. Also, after watching the clone wars episode where the scene is from it all makes perfect sense. It is also very close to the actual ship from both the clone wars series and the movie. I actually appreciate the ship.

Minifigures.


The set comes with a total of three minifigures, all unique in their own way.

A4-D is the droid, the general's personal medic/assistant. There are plenty of tools that come along with him and it has a cool sort of sand-coloured texture. It's face is a sticker, which I would have wanted to have been a printed piece (it might be cheaper for LEGO to just create stickers, so I understand it. It doesn't mean I have to like it.). 

General Grievous. He's the major draw for this set, a stunning figure. Very spot-on, wonderfully detailed and a truly nice addition to your space-villain collection. The armour rocks! His face is printed and the extra arms makes him look a bit intimidating (brick-style!) to any galaxy warrior who'd be unfortunate to encounter him! He has the similar colour to A4-D and added some grey here and there. Movability is ace with this one. You can pose him quite well.

Nahdar Vebb is both new and old. Not the actual figure of course, but he has the same head as other LEGO Mon Calamari people (Ackbar, Calamari Officer) from the Home One Mon Calamari Cruiser. In itself the head is a great piece for creating your own MOC calamari gang. Jumping back from my sideline and on to the actual review, I think Nahdar is pretty cool and the printing on the torso feels accurate to the episode. Other than that, there's really nothing special about him as such, just a good minifigure.

The lair.


A lair? Well, I find it hard to picture the chair and the lightsaber-stand as a lair. Of course I'm an adult and may view things a bit differently. But even for youngsters, I think LEGO should have made an extra effort to kickstart their imagination. Why not include half a room with sliding doors and a small command centre? For the price of the set, I think there should be more bricks. But on the positive side, the chair fills its purpose and Grievous fits nicely there. You get a bunch of lightsabers too.

Starship.


I am a big fan of this republic-era ship. Lately a couple of ships from the Star Wars line have a flight and landing model. This is not an exception. If you are a younger person, this is very easy to "fly" around with. All you need is to turn the brick up at the end of the ship, and you're set to go, either to Geonosis or some other dodgy place in the galaxy. For display in a collector's home or workplace, this ship looks great from the distance and even more impressive when you have a close-up look. I like how the cockpit opens on this ship. There are also "hidden" missiles on the sides and a bigger bomb/missile under the actual ship.

Conclusion.


This is a good buy, preferably on sale. If you don't have General Grievous I am inclined to ask you to get this set. I haven't got the old Grievous but from what I've seen pictures, THIS figure is a huuuuge improvement. A great set for collecting and if you are a youngster, you will have tons of fun playing with it.


Pros:
  • Well-constructed ship and easy to handle.
  • General Grievous!
  • Accurate and true to the originals (series/film).

Cons:
  • I'm not too impressed with the lair-part. It does need something more.

author: Huge_Nerd
title: A salute to the General
review:
I got this set recently for 40% off at a local toy store and it was well worth.  The ship, Soulless One, is nice and large, and very swooshable. The play-features are well-done, but not obtrusive: the flick-fires fold away and are hidden perfectly and the large bomb nestles nicely underneath. The sliding cockpit works like a charm, and I especially was impressed how the rubber piece was used to keep the cockpit cover in place when closed. The end result is quite accurate to its appearance in Episode III and the Clone Wars. I used to play a lot Battlefront II, and this ship serves as the CIS bomber as well. The ship itself is reminiscent of a 1950s automobile in it general shape, and the side exhaust pipes are similar to that of some hot rods. 

The build is quite interesting with a variety of techniques employed.  The two side thrusters, while mirrored, are complex enough to not feel repetitive. 

The "lair" is good for what it is--basically a dentist's chair. The chair looks nice and Grievous sits in it well. The storage for his gun and lightsabers is helpful.

The minifigs in this set are quite well-done.  General Grievous is amazing and very detailed.  You can adjust his arms enough so that he can hold his lightsabers at different angles as if he is spinning and swing them.  Since Grievous does only deploy two-arms often, it is good that that look is an option (the two-arm look is also necessary for him to fit in the cockpit of the starfighter). When not using the two extra arms, I clip them on the side bars on the chair, and fold them behind the chair-back where they are not even noticeable.

Nahdar Vebb is a pretty standard Jedi, but with a rare and well-sculped Mon Calimari head.  A4-D seems to be a pretty unique droud. The legs are standard battle droid legs, but I'm not sure how the torso has been used before--it's more robust than a battle droids.  His sticker, while not ideal, works well enough. I've found that he stands quite well if you arrange pose his tool arms in such a way to hold the lights and round tray where he might actually use them. 

Overall, this set is a must-have for any General Grievous fan and is a welcome addition to any lineup of Lego starfighter models.

author: Mandalorian
title: Nice, solid fighter.
review:
I have had this set for a long time by now, it's very nice but a bit boring. The building experience is very enjoyable and fairly long. The mechanism for the sliding cockpit is ingenious and it works really well, as a part of the cockpit clicks into position when closed, preventing it from sliding open. The piece used for the click is also used as a pretty decent representation of the original steering mechanism in the starfighter. For a medium-sized set, this one is very solid and quite heavy. The way that the flick missiles are hidden in the engines is incredibly clever and continues to impress me to this day. Despite the lack of landing gear, this set looks pretty good on display. The minifigures are very nice (Grievous is absolutely amazing!), but I feel there should have been a Kit Fisto included, as he plays a large role in the episode this set is based on. The chair/bed is nice, but I'm not so keen on the lightsaber holder, as it is terribly unrealistic.
Pros:
  • Nice, solid starfighter
  • General Grievous is amazing
  • The other minifigs are also nice
  • Ingenious cockpit closing mechanism
  • Flick missiles are well built into the ship
  • Enjoyable build
  • Fairly swooshable
  • Some nice parts (cockpit)

Cons:

  • Rather small for the price
  • No Kit Fisto
  • Can get a bit boring
  • Lightsaber holder is a dumb idea IMO.

Even though I don't own the previous General Grievous' Starfighter, it is obvious that this one is an improvement over it in almost every possible way. If you want this set, buy it, it's a nice model and a fun build, but you can get better stuff for a similar price.

author: jango_e1_g3
title: One of the COOLEST sets I own!!
review:
Wow. This is such a great set, it is such a improvment from the previuos version in both figures and fetures and over all design.Before I begin I should tell you this is from the clone wars episode ''The Lair Of Grrievous''.On to the review!

First the minifigs:General Grievous:This has got to be one of the coolest figures of 2010,Grievous has a new body,legs and head as well as a new arm piece that lets you atch anouther arm on to it.This is good and bad because that means he can only hold them side ways, which doesnt look very cool.This can be fixed by put the hand part on to the arm insted,but of course you can come up with your on way.Still,he looks prety impresive.He is armed with his four lightsabers and a blaster.

A4-D4:This is a well decepted figure of Grievous's caretaker and repair droid.He has a lamp on one soulder and some sort of wheel thing,which I cant think what it's for,on the other.On his hands there's a small saw and a grasper that can hold Grievous's arms.Relly a cool figure.

Nahader Vebb:Nahader was Kit Fisto's aprentence before he got shot by Greivous.He has a duble sided cheast and a head thats in one other set.His lightsaber is a new metel crome finsh which looks a little better then the old ones.

The lair/repair center:This  is suposed to be the command center inside Grievous castle,fortress thing.Its small and has a rack for his lightsabers and blaster and his chair,which actuly fits him nicly.The only thing is its a bit cramped but thats it and its a welcome adition to this set.

The Ship:Awsome, just pure awsomeness.The front of the ship has the nose cones and front laser cannons,which can tilt up and down.It also has the brown and tan paint job.On the sides of the ship have radiator fins and (wait for it!) hidden missile luanchers! You cant tell it all that there there when they are closed and you dont have to fold them all the way dowen ether.But they are the goofy flick-fire missiles,which work sometimes,but still cool. The cockpit has a nice sliding fature and it locks shut thanks to a rubber piece.The intier has two sticker control panels and Grievous fits in there nicly.Lastly the fin thing on the back of the ship folds up when flying.Also,theirs a missile atatced to the bottom of the ship.I'm not sure what its for but you can flick it of like a bowb and it looks cool.

 

Last thoughts,a relly cool set that has one of my favorite guys from star wars in it.It works nicly as both clone wars and episode III.But its fifty bucks which is farly high but it is worth it in the long run.Buy it if you have the money,becouse this might be the last set with General Grievous in it.

author: StratTone
title: This one has it all.
review: Lego did a great job on the cockpit of this ship and grevious!  Very fun to build, great figures, playablitly, and great eye candy!  For the price vs. fun you get your moneys worth.  Where were these sets when I was a kid?  lol  I can't complain though we did have better space sets when I was young.

author: ccjwprongs
title: The Good General's Great Starfighter
review:
I never picked up the original incarnation of General Grievous' Starfighter - set 7656 - modelled after the Revenge of the Sith version. I liked the ship, and I liked Grievous, but something about the lacklustre LEGO design of both craft and minifigure of the first set put me off. Imagine my delight when an upgrade as gorgeous as this one came along.

Box/Instructions

The box features the fantastic 2010/11 Clone Wars artwork, doused in blue hues and Captain Rex. I was always fond of it (so I'm less enthused about Darth Maul emblazoning Star Wars merch from 2012 onwards). The set itself is displayed equally well, and showcases the three (all new) minifigures. The instructions are a cinch to follow and shouldn't trouble any capable builders.

Parts

Plenty of decent parts to be had here; dozens of 1x2 tiles, a nice helping of dark bley plates and a smashing new canopy. There's also five lightsabers (it is Grievous after all), each with the shiny metallic hilts that have become the norm in recent Star Wars sets. There's a dash of Technic which is a nice inclusion (to both the parts and the build, but more on that later). On the downside, we have the usual sticker sheet...

Minifigures

...which even makes its way onto the minifigures. Medical droid EV-A4D's head, comprised of a 1 x 2 x 1 1/3 Curved Top brick, carries the most miniscule of stickers you'll ever come across. It's a pain to get on, and makes you long for the days of printed bricks more than ever. Though the droid itself is fairly useless anyway, with standard parts (apart from maybe the torso) and practically no balance.

Aside from that niggle, we get Nahdar Vebb, who's a perfect recreation of the Clone Wars character, and also a much cheaper way to get hold of a Mon Calamari head than Home One, and a stunningly updated and upgraded General Grievous. I've heard people complain about the Clone Wars TV show far too often for my liking; sure, the dialogue's a bit dubious, and the voice acting even more so, but it's enjoyable enough. But I digress.

The real reason to like the Clone Wars show is this: the Grievous minifigure accompanying this set. It's a fantastically menacing representation, even if a tad too un-LEGO-y (that's definitely a term) for some. The posture is exquisitely captured through the neck and bent legs that move individually of one another, and the printing is all superb. If I were to have one complaint, it would be the way the second pair of arms attach - while it allows for some cool poses, the arms should technically split into two, rather than the second pair extending at crazy angles from the first.

That aside, this is a seriously cool lineup of minifigures. At the price range it's also pretty decent for today's sets, though considering one is brickbuilt it wouldn't have hurt to chuck in a Clone Trooper or something.

The Build

Nothing tricky here, and a fairly swift build. Definitely enjoyable though, if a little repetitive when it comes to the mirrored engines. There's some interesting design choices though, and the sliding cockpit is genius. The inevitable flickfire missiles find their way in, but only under a hinged mechanism that cleverly hides them in the engines, for when we don't want to see eight bright orange cones sticking out of our starfighter.

Summary

There's not much I can say about this upgrade, apart from that it's totally badass. And pretty damn meaty too. Stand it next to the original incarnation, and poor old 7656 will likely be found the next day dismantling itself for parts in humiliation. The former attempt was half the price, sure, but also half the awesomeness. Released in the age when LEGO was all about using huge, specialist parts as a half-hearted attempt at 'slopes' (see the second Sith Infiltrator for further example), the original didn't have much in the way of 'wow' factor.

Luckily, 8095 does. Packing serious punch, with some pretty dandy play features and some kickass minifigures, there's not much more you could ask for. Except printed bricks. And even more minifigures. But you can't have everything. Suffice to say it's definitely a highlight of the Star Wars system line-up in recent years, and one of the few sets I'd recommend at full price. Buy it quick before it's discontinued forever. I guarantee you won't regret it.

author: wii1232
title: Jedi Scum!
review:
The box was huge for the size of the set, but all those bags and the instruction booklet need some extra room to move around to torture the person who's shaking it:)

Anyways, now to the set.  The three new and exclusive minifigs included Nahdar Vebb, A4-D, and the General himself(at the time, because obviously now he's also in 9515 The Malevolence)!  The features are cool, the sliding cockpit, hidden flick missiles, the rocket underneath, moveable laser cannons, a swiveling chair with a recliner, a lightsaber/blaster rack, etc.

author: tomalphin
title: Some nice techniques, small for the price.
review:
About me: I am an AFOL who has been building at least 1 set each year for my whole life. I build a lot of sets under 500 pieces as a "puzzle build", without using the instructions, but used the instructions to build this.

Initial impressions: I have no connection to the Clone Wars, so this review is based solely on the parts, the construction techniques and finished build.

Building experience: I do enjoy how it was hard to see how the model was going to come together till the end.  The modules are cleverly constructed and reasonably solid.

Finished Model: I like the use of tiles which are partially covered to achieve striped effect.  I also enjoyed the hidden weaponry, and the sliding cockpit.

Conclusion: This is a perfectly reasonable build, albeit slightly overpriced at an MSRP of 50$ US.

author: Bricky_Dee_Williams
title: Starfighter Fit For a General.
review:
Box/Instructions

The box in this set was a pretty good size. And by that I mean it's huge, but fits the bags and wide instruction booklet.(And warning, it rolls up easily and is a pain to flatten out. I got this set in a shoebox on my birthday) Anyway, the instructions are pretty easy to follow, though at some points it's hard to distinguish the many dark-grey pieces from the black pieces. However, it's still a generally good system to follow.

Parts

There is a very diverse selection of pieces in the set, including the long front gray piece that slopes down and covers most of the pieces below it, and helps to hold the front of the model together. The windshield piece is a pretty neat piece, and I believe is exclusive to the set. (It wasn't in the last one) There are plenty of specially molded pieces on the Grievous minifigure, and Admiral Ackabar's head is used on Nahdar Vebb. Plus, for $50 (original price) you get 454 pieces, so it's a pretty fair amount of pieces, especially with the minifigures.

Minifigures

As mentioned before, you get the General Grievous and Nahdar Vebb minifigures. Now, there is one problem with Grievous: his head detaches easily. (Must be a malfunction in the cyborg build) Otherwise, he is a great figure, with really cool pieces for the legs and a new specially molded torso. Nahdar is pretty basic pieces, not counting the head. Grievous' droid is another story. A4-D includes a variety of tan and dark grey pieces, and has some equipment for rebuilding the general attached to his backside. He's a bit hard to keep standing if not on a baseplate, but a great figure all the same. And one more thing: His face is a STICKER. A sticker.

The build

The construction part of the set is a complex (ish) but somewhat easy build. Parts may seem repetitive, like laying the same brown to tan pattern in the first few steps, building the same missiles or the same elevating laser blasters or the same side pieces with the opening missile compartments. Building the cockpit and windshield section itself is cool, with the control panels (which are stickers, sadly) is fun. It's a good experience.

The completed model

The model is an upgrade from the 2007 model, with more complex building to be done, It is also a bit bigger, and include the hidden missile that attaches to the ship's underside and the flick fire missiles. The windshield to the entrance of the cockpit still slides forward, and the tail fin still elevates in back. However this model includes a chair. A very random chair. A very random reclining chair for the General to be repaired in. The side stand still includes a rack for the lightsaber storage, and a gun this time around. Super-cool model.

Overall opinion

A fantastic Star Wars set. A very well made set. This set tops the 2007 version, which was very basic in many ways. This set's playability is very good, with hidden missiles seemingly everywhere, and blasters that rise up and down on top of the ship. The set balances well when the tail fin is down, and provides for a great display.

Pros:

-Grat minifigures

-Great Playability

-Good sized Star Wars set, bigger than last version.

 

Cons:

-General Grievous has a screw loose: his head falls off.
